description:
The pandas library represents a very efficient and convenient tool
for data manipulation, but sometimes hides unexpected pitfalls which
can arise in various and sometimes unintelligible ways.

By briefly referring to some aspects of the implementation, I will
review specific situations in which a change of approach can make
code based on pandas more robust, or more performant.

Some examples:

- inefficient indexing
- multiple dtypes and efficiency
- implicit type casting
- HDF5 storage overhead
- GroupBy.apply()... when you don't actually need it

UPDATE: slides and materials can be found at http://pietrobattiston.it/python:pycon#europython_rimini_july_2017
title: How to use pandas the wrong way
